section.title: Introduction
section.para: This feature of OTRS allows you to model processes (workflows) in the ticket system. The basic idea is to be able to define reoccurring processes, and to delegate work items to different people, as well as leading the progress of a process in different directions based on certain criteria.

section.title: Example process
section.para: Let's see an example to make it more demonstrative. We will define a book order process:

section.title: Recording the demand
section.para: Before an order will be placed, the demand for literature by an employee will be recorded. The following book is needed in our example:

para.screen: Title: Prozessmanagement f√ºr Dummies Autor: Thilo Knuppertz ISBN: 3527703713

section.title: Approval by superior
section.para: The head of the employee's department needs to decide on the order. In case of a denial, a reason should be recorded by the superior. In case of approval, the order is passed to the purchasing department.

section.title: Processing by purchasing department
section.para: Purchasing now has the task to find out where the book can be ordered with the best conditions. If it is out of stock, this can be recorded in the order. In case of a successful order purchasing will record the supplier, the price and the delivery date.

section.title: Processing by the mailroom
section.para: The shipment will arrive at the company. The incoming goods department checks the shipment and records the date of receipt. Now the employee will be informed that their order has arrived and is ready to be collected.

section.title: Implementing the example
section.para: If we assume that a ticket acts in this workflow like an accompanying document that can receive change notes, we already have a clear picture of process tickets.
From the analysis of the example process we can identify the following neccessary items:

listitem.para: Possiblities to record data, let's call them Activity Dialogs,
checks which can react to changed data automatically, let's call them Transitions,
changes which can be applied to a process ticket after successful transitions of a process ticket, let's call them Transition Actions.

section.para: We also need an additional item which might not be as obvious:

listitem.para: A possibility to offer more than just one Activity Dialog to be available. In our example this is needed when the superior must have the choice between "Approve" and "Deny". Let's call this Activity.

section.para: Now, with Activities, Activity Dialogs, Transitions and Transition Actions we have the neccessary tools to model the individual steps of our example. To be able to refer to these entities later, we will assign to them an abbreviation in parentheses.
What's still missing is an area where for each workflow the order of the steps can be specified. Let's call this Process.
In the next step, we will define the individual entities that we need.

listitem.para: "Recoding the demand" (AD1): An Activity Dialog that contains all the required fields for the data to be collected for the order (Title, Author and ISBN), and a status field with the possibility to choose "Approval".
"Approval denied" (AD2): An Activity Dialog with a comment field and a status field with the option "Approval denied".
"Approved " (AD3): Here we just need the status field with the option "Approved".

"Order rejected" (AD4): An activity dialog which makes it possible for purchasing to reject an impossible order (book out of stock). Here we also need a comment field and the status field with the option "Order denied".
"Order placed" (AD5): An activity dialog with the fields supplier, price and delivery date for purchasing and the status field with the option "Order placed".
"Shipment received" (AD6): An activity for the mailroom with a field for the date of receipt and the status field with the option "Shipment received".
"Approval" (T1): A transition which checks if the status field is set to "Approval".
"Approval denied" (T2): A transition which checks if the status field is set to "Approval denied".
"Approved" (T3): A transition which checks if the status field is set to "Approved".
"Order denied" (T4): A transition which checks if the status field is set to "Order denied".
"Order placed" (T5): A transition which checks if the status field is set to "Order placed".
"Shipment received" (T6): A transition which checks if the status field is set to "Shipment received".

section.title: TransitionActions

listitem.para: Moving the process ticket into the "Superior" queue. (TA1): This action is supposed to be executed when the Transition "Approval" applied.
Change ticket responsible to "Superior". (TA2): To be executed when the Transition "Approval" applied.
Move the process ticket to the "Employee" Queues. (TA3): To be executed when:
the Transition "Approval denied" applied
the Transition "Order denied" applied
the Transition "Shipment received" applied
Change ticket responsible to "Employee". (TA4): To be executed when:
the transition "Approval denied" applied
the transition "Oder denied" applied
the transition "Shipment received" applied
Move process ticket to Queue "Purchasing". (TA5): To be executed when the transition "Approved" applied.
Move process ticket to Queue "Post office". (TA6): To be executed when the transition "Order placed" applied.

section.para: As you can see, there are places where the same TransitionAction should be executed. Therefore it is reasonable to make it possible to link TransitionActions freely with Transitions to be able to reuse them.

section.title: Activities
section.para: We chose the approach to see Activities as a basket which can contain one or more Activity Dialogs. We need these Activities for our example:

listitem.para: Recording the demand (A1): Contains the Activity Dialog "Recording the demand"
Approval (A2): Contains the Activity Dialogs "Approval denied" as well as "Approved"
Order (A3): Contains the Activity Dialogs "Order denied" as well as "Order placed"
Incoming (AS): Contains the Activity Dialog "Shipment received"
Process complete (A5): This is an Activity without possible ActivityDialogs. It will be set after "Approval denied", "Order denied" or "Shipment received" and represents the end of the process.

section.para: Now we can clearly see that Activities are precisely defined states of a process ticket. After a successful Transition a process ticket moves from one Activity to another.

section.title: Book ordering Process
section.para: Let us conclude our example with the last missing piece in the puzzle, the Process. In our case this is the whole ordering workflow. Other processes could be office supply ordering or completely different processes.

The process has a starting point which consists of the start Activity and the start Activity Dialog. For any new book order, the start Activity Dialog is the first screen that is displayed. If this is completed and saved, the Process ticket will be created and can follow the configured workflow.

The process also contains the directions for how the process ticket can move through the Process. Let's call this the "Path". It consists of the start Activity, one or more Transitions (possibly with Transition Actions), and other Activities.
Recording the demand until "Approval"

listitem.para: Starting point: Activity A1 (Recording the demand)
Possible Transition: T1 (Approval)
If the condition of this activity is fulfilled, the ticket will move to Activity A2 (Approval)
Additionally, the following TransitionActions are executed:
TA1 (Moving the ticket into the "Superior" Queue)
TA2 (Set ticket responsible to "Superior")

section.para: That's the first step in the path of the book ordering process. It looks like this (slightly simplified):

Action 'A1' is a defined state of the process ticket, where there is the possibility for the Transition 'T1'. If this applies, the ticket will move to the next Activity 'A2', and the TransitionActions 'TA1' and 'TA2' are executed. In Activity 'A2', the Activity Dialogs 'AD2' (Approval denied) and 'AD3' (Approved) are available.
Approval

listitem.para: Starting Point: Activity A2 (Approval)
Possible Transitions:
T2 (Approval denied)
If this matches, the process ticket will move to Activity A5 (Process complete).
Additionally, the following TransitionActions are executed:
TA3 (move process ticket to the "Employee" Queue)
TA4 (set ticket responsible to "Employee")
T3 (Approved)
If this matches, the process ticket will move to Activity A3 (Order).
Additionally, the following TransitionAction is executed:
TA5 (move process ticket to "Purchasing" Queue)
